job: Senior Scientist, Krembil Research Institute at UHN
bio: Dr. Frances Skinner is a Senior Scientist in the Krembil Research Institute at UHN and a Full Professor at UofT. Dr. Skinner completed Postdoctoral Fellowships in Boston and California, and received her MASc and PhD in Biomedical Engineering at UofT. Dr. Skinner’s lab (http://www.skinnerlab.org/) develops computational neuronal and circuit models, combining electrophysiology, mathematical modeling and theory to understand how these circuits behave and to investigate abnormalities in brain disorders.

job: Scientist, Campbell Family Mental Health Research Institute at CAMH
bio: Dr. Yuliya Nikolova is an Independent Scientist in the Campbell Family Mental Health Research Institute at CAMH. Dr. Nikolova completed her Postdoctoral Fellowship in Translational Neuroscience at CAMH, and received her PhD in Psychology and Neuroscience at Duke University. Dr. Nikolova’s lab integrates genetics, neuorimaging, and clinical research to investigate mechanisms of risk for mental illness.

job: Scientist, Krembil Centre for Neuroinformatics at CAMH
bio: Dr. Andreea Diaconescu is an Independent Scientist in the Krembil Centre for Neuroinformatics at CAMH. Dr. Diaconescu completed her Postdoctoral Fellowship in Translational Neuromodeling at the University of Zurich and ETH Zurich, and received her PhD in the Rotman Research Institute at UofT. Dr. Diaconescu’s lab uses multimodal neuroimaging and computational modeling to understand how psychosis impacts social learning and decision-making.

Dr. Morgan Barense is an Associate Scientist at the Rotman Research Institute, Full Professor at UofT and director of the Toronto Neuroimaging Facility (ToNI). Dr. Barense completed her PhD and Postdoctoral Fellowship at the University of Cambridge. Her lab seeks to understand the neural and behavioural mechanisms of memory and how memory is affected through aging, brain damage or disease.

job: Scientist, Krembil Centre for Neuroinformatics at CAMH
bio: Dr. Daniel Felsky is an Independent Scientist in the Krembil Centre for Neuroinformatics at CAMH and an Assistant Professor at UofT. Dr. Felsky completed Postdoctoral Fellowships at Brigham and Women’s Hospital Harvard Medical School and the Centre for Translational and Computational Neuroimmunology at Columbia University. Dr. Felsky has experience working with structural brain imaging, human genomics and transcriptomics, and biostatistics and will incorporate these techniques in his new role as the Head of Whole Person Modeling in the KCNI.
